body: I don't understand your setup. `B` considers `Server` untrusted. `Server` apparently considers `B` untrusted. Why?

Thanks for the quick reply!  

I marked B as untrusted on Server. I forgot I had done that, sorry, definitely should've included it.  
I want to be sure Server never sends anything unencrypted to B. B is actually another person's device, who I allow to use Server to simplify syncing between devices that aren't necessarily online at the same time. Basically a laptop and a phone.

So my understanding is with 1.23.6, Server no longer considers a folder received as encrypted safe to share with an untrusted peer. I think that's a valid use case as my situation is not too weird :)

Yeah, I think the situation for re-sharing already-encrypted data isn't especially polished...

For `untrusted`, I guess you can see it as a flag to say the other side cannot be trusted with the data we have without additional encryption. When sending already-encrypted data the other side is not less trusted than you are, you're at the same trust level.

This is causing some errors. My friend and I are using synching to cross backup each others information. They have a synching set to untrusted and set a password for the share, and I set them to be untrusted with a password for my share. I am running 1.23.4 and I can accept their share but they cannot accept my share and they are on 1.23.6.

> This is causing some errors. My friend and I are using synching to cross backup each others information. They have a synching set to untrusted and set a password for the share, and I set them to be untrusted with a password for my share. I am running 1.23.4 and I can accept their share but they cannot accept my share and they are on 1.23.6.

Can confirm this. The following configuration does not work when "my device" is running 1.23.6, and "their device" is running 1.23.4:
- their device and my device both mark each other as untrusted
- their folder is shared (as encrypted) with my device
- when I accept the share (as receive encrypted), my device unshares it and a notice pops up saying: "Folder { their folder } is shared in trusted mode with untrusted device { their device }; unsharing."
- The only workaround I've found is to not mark "their device" as untrusted, which means my device cannot use the "untrusted" functionality. Having them delete "their folder" on "their device", recreate it, then share it with my device didn't help.

It is noted that the reverse setup (my device shares encrypted folder with device running 1.23.4) does not have this same issue. To confirm, I have downgraded my device to 1.23.5, marked "their device" as untrusted, and the share works as expected. When I upgrade back to 1.23.6, the share is immediately unshared like described above.

It seems that commit 6b475bdb78eb671866419ff84a4cda6285c90244 is the source of this bug, or reveals a bug elsewhere. Is there anything I can do to help troubleshoot this?

For some context on the use case for a configuration like this, this allows two people to provide offsite backup as well as redundancy to each other without revealing the contents of each person's data. It's very useful.
Right, it should be possible to have receive-encrypted folders from an untrusted device.

> That seems about correct, yes.

Ok, I'll test this change and if it seems to work I'll submit a PR for review.

Thanks

I'm hit by what could be a variation of this bug, possibly with a common root cause, since updating to 1.23.6, but probably specific to Windows:

My setup:

3 devices: server (Debian 11, running 24/7), notebook (Windows 10), desktop (Ubuntu 22.04), all in the same LAN.
All devices are trusting each other and are sharing multiple shares.
Some data ("crypto" share) must be encrypted on the server by organizational policy, but is o.k. to reside normally on desktop and notebook (their disks are fully encrypted, server's disk is not), so I'm using this setup for the crypto share:
@Desktop, @Notebook: sharing normally to each other, but sharing encrypted to server
@Server: share type is "receive encrypted"


Expected behaviour:
All 3 devices consider all others connected and do exchange data.

Actual behaviour:

Server and Notebook consider each other disconnected. That's the problem.
Desktop is connecting fine to Server and Notebook.
Notebook is connecting to Desktop but not to Server.
Server is connecting to Desktop but not to Notebook.


The observation that only the Notebook is having issues makes me think that this is bug is Windows specific and encryption specific, because it works unencrypted between Windows and Linux and it works encrypted between Linux and Linux.

### Purpose
Fixes #8965. 

Safety check added in v1.23.6 introduced bug. Bug unshares folders with untrusted devices if folder does not have an encryption password set, regardless of whether the folder is shared with the untrusted device as encrypted or not. Prevents sharing with untrusted devices in some cases where sharing would be encrypted.

Patch preserves safety check but permits sharing folders with untrusted devices if they are shared as encrypted.

### Testing
Tested on 2023/07/31 as follows:
- Compiled syncthing from main with and without this patch
- Ran both syncthing binaries concurrently
- Added both syncthing instances as mutually untrusted devices.
- Shared one folder per instance with the other as encrypted
As expected, the unmodified syncthing instance automatically deleted its shared folder (consistent with v1.23.6 bugged behaviour). The patched syncthing instance did not (consistent with pre-v1.23.6 behaviour before safety check and bug was introduced).
